subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4
msgSnippet: In my experience you can also get annoying errors  (no such method etc) if you use methods that are only available in Java 1.5. Sometimes it is obvious which
messageBody:
In my experience you can also get annoying errors (no such method
etc) if you use methods that are only available in Java 1.5. Sometimes
it is obvious which ones they are. Sometimes not so obvious without
checking javadoc which is more tedious than code-completion. I would
feel much more comfortable using the same JDK for development, testing
*and* production. It is not imposible to solve these "problems" but in
my booke it's more trouble than it's worth.

Of course YMMV



> On 9/13/06, Neil Swingler <neil@...> wrote:
> >
> > Surely even if java 5 is not permitted in production code there can be
> > no harm in using it to run a unit testing tool. Indeed starting with
> > java 5 features in unit tests would be a good way to practice them
> > without risking all on the production code.
> >
> > - Neil
